results.title: Leah; Water rats; Alison; Tracey
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Health and Sabina Baltrukomis
results.brief_description: A compilation tape consisting of four programmes designed to promote discussion in the area of human relations. 1. Leah. Concerns the feelings of an adolescent girl in regard to her alcoholic father who embarrasses her in front of her friends. 2. Water rats. Looks at the peer pressure exerted amongst a group of adolescents to conform to the group’s standards. 3. Alison. Looks at the problems of an adolescent girl who cannot adjust to her single father’s need to have adult female companionship. 4 Tracey. Considers the situation of an adolescent girl subjected to pressure by her domineering father to perform well academically.

results.title: [The Tatler social newsreel]
results.brief_description: This film was one of the many documentaries shot in Victoria by Efftee Studios in the early 30s. In this newsreel compiled and narrated by Peter Newmarch of “The Truth” newspaper and shot by Bert Nicholas, several Melbourne socialites are featured at various functions: a social party in South Yarra, the first official meeting of the Centenary Dog Club at the Melbourne Showground and Ron Cameron’s Riding School. NOTE: No titles included.

results.title: Factory to farm
results.brief_description: Shows the various stages in the manufacture of farm implements and machinery and their use on Australian wheat farms during the 1920s. An important film on Australian history, both from farming and the “Sunshine Harvester Factory” points of view. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Versatility in glass
results.brief_description:
Public relations film outlining the nature of glass: how it is made; how it can be used in its many and varied forms for decoration, safety and protection in the home, industry and transportation.
Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Kampuchea: the long road back
results.creator_credit: Leonard Teale, John Wall and Canterbury Productions
results.brief_description: Commissioned by the sponsors of the Kampuchean Relief Appeal this made for television documentary shows how donations to International Relief Aid were used to bring aid to Kampuchea. Also records the plight of Kampucheans still struggling for survival after the death and destruction caused by the Pol Pot regime. Narrated by Leonard Teale.

results.title: For Better - For Worse
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale, Don Anderson and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Dramatization of common misconceptions surrounding marriage and the types of stress contributing to marriage breakdown. Refers to alcohol, the consequences of “mateship” and violence.

results.title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, Nick Bosustow, David Adams and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: Visualizes the spectral spirits and twilight superstitions that haunted the drowsy Dutch settlement of Sleepy Hollow. Concerns the rivalry between Ichabod Crane and Brom Bones for the hand of Katrina Van Tassel, and how the Headless Horseman of Sleepy Hollow removes Ichabod from the scene. Screenplay by Joseph Cavella, based on the story by Washington Irving. Narrated by John Carradine.

results.title: Shearing Yaks (Tajik People)
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Explains how the yak herds, which stay high in the mountains, where it is cool, are brought down to the village for shearing. The wool is pounded by men with sticks, spun into yarn and kept until there is enough to make a carpet. Shows the Tajik people shearing yaks.

results.title: The Seven bridges of Koenigsberg
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cornwell and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An animated film concerned with solving the problem of crossing the seven bridges of Koenigsberg, Germany, in a single continuous walk. Early attempts to solve it by trial and error are shown, including Leonard Euler’s analysis of the problem. This is a clearly explained and attractive film which would complement a study on topology or network theory. No other credits available. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
